review_title: Great College with Questionable Leadership in Advancement
job_title: Assistant Director of Annual Giving in Claremont, CA
pros:
- This is a top 10 liberal arts college in the US. 
- The staff are friendly and mostly seem to enjoy what they do. 
- The campus is beautiful, and it's small, so you can get to know staff, faculty, and students easily. 
- The College's administration went to great lengths to not permanently lay off staff during the pandemic. 
- Everyone who was furloughed will be brought back.
- Good benefits.
cons:
- Leadership in Advancement is weak. They often flip-flop between decisions.
- There is a lack of overall appreciation for the hard work teams put into meeting annual goals. A "thank you" is usually replaced with a "great work, but what more can we do?"
- Could be due to the pandemic, but newcomers can feel like outsiders among the tight-knit alumni, parent, and long-term staff community. An alumnus once referred to a non-alumni staff member as just "the help".

pros: Healthy budget and generous benefits package
cons: PWI with a glaring lack of POC employees in leadership positions and especially faculty.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA

pros:
Working at CMC's Career Services center as a Career Consultant is a good gig. While it can be stressful at times when many students are in the office requiring your assistance, the office is often quite allowing time to do homework or pursue other interests. 

The staff are amazing. Students are involved in decision making and are constantly be asked for input of all varieties. Very transparent. Generally an open door policy with the staff. 

There is always coffee and often pastries of some sort brought in by a staff member. 

Fellow Career Consultants are very reliable and generous about covering shifts, even if it's last minute.
cons: During busy times, specifically during the beginning of the year, you can be asked to work multiple info sessions as well as Career Fairs and open houses. This can be stressful but for the majority of the year the expected hours are very minimal. Although there is almost always an opportunity to up your hours by covering someone's shift or working an info session or other event.

pros: Nice campus and location. Exceptional students. Could have been a great place to work. Glassdoor has Pamela Gann down as the CEO. She is long ago stepped down more's the pity.
cons:
I'm with the person who said CMC operates on a "lean staffing" model at the lower levels. Staff leaves, you just get to do more work when they aren't replaced. Like it's expected and you're not supposed to notice. This might be acceptable especially if it were only temporary for a few months if salaries were commensurate with demands, but they're not. 

Advice to Management

review_title: CMC has wonderful students and great research opportunities.
pros: CMC has wonderful students and great research opportunitities. There are multiple research institutes in a variety of fields that are of tremendous help to faculty.
cons: lop-sided curricular emphasis on two departments; this makes those two departments wonderfully strong but difficult if you are a have-not

review_title: Support higher education and have fund doing it.
job_title: Director of Annual Giving in Claremont, CA
pros: Dedicated workforce, great benefits, wonderful learning opportunities, working in a college town, positive interactions with students, alumni and parents, professional growth opportunities.
cons: Although faculty is diverse and open-minded, many staff members are very religious and don't understand (or try to understand) non-Christians. Sometimes their religious beliefs are stated clearly on issues that should not be discussed in the workplace. This can create an uncomfortable envirnonment when it occurs.

review_title: Not a bad place to work
job_title: Web Content Assistant in Claremont, CA
pros: Claremont is a beautiful campus and a great college (situated next to the other four Claremont Colleges). The small student body size makes for a great but still well-connected community.
cons: People sometimes get stuck in the "Claremont Bubble" and get a little out of touch with reality. Otherwise, the work experience is pleasant and the compensation is appropriate for student employment.

pros: There are probably good departments to work in, but Development isn't one of them.
cons: Poor management. Bean-counter mentality. Good at talking the talk, sounds good but sounding good is about as far as it goes. Turnover very high, nearing 50% in the last 2 or so years. The best employees have been leaving to work at better places. Not all who leave are replaced, just push more work onto someone else.

pros: The people working at CMC are extremely helpful, intelligent and kind. Everyone is willing to  help you gain new necessary skills, the environment is friendly and comfortable, and the offices and campus is gorgeous especially with all of the new construction.
cons: There really are no cons at CMC.

pros: I worked an on campus job. It was good part-time work while being a student. They pay decently and understand that classes are a priority
cons: I have nothing negative to say about my employment there. See my section on "pros" for further clarification.
